This document describes the guidelines and requirements for the deployment of Blue Planet products using the Kubernetes, Red Hat OpenShift, and Blue Planet (BP2) platforms.
This guide discusses how to prepare the environment for deploying the Blue Planet products. The guide covers the requirements for deploying the following products and the combination of products:
Customers and professional services can use this document to understand the requirements for installing the Blue Planet products and plan the installation accordingly.
Blue Planet offers a variety of products that can be deployed on the following supported platforms:

When you deploy Blue Planet products using the Blue Planet native platform, you use Blue Planet Installer (BPI) to set up the Blue Planet platform, and lineup files to deploy Blue Planet solutions. The lineup files are either compressed in a TAR file (available at Ciena portal) or these are available online on bphub.

In order to deploy the Blue Planet products, you need to download or avail the required installation files and then set up the platform. These installation files include Blue Planet Installer script, lineup files, among other required files.

Kubernetes is an open source container orchestration platform that automates many of the manual processes involved in deploying, managing, and scaling containerized applications. You can cluster together groups of nodes running containers, and Kubernetes helps you easily and efficiently manage those clusters.

You can deploy Blue Planet products on cloud using the Kubernetes platform, which means that you use Kubernetes infrastructure (a combination of resources including servers, physical or virtual machines, cloud platforms and more) to deploy your products. You first need to set up you EKS, AKS, or GKE cluster as per your deployment needs and then deploy the products on it.

Red Hat Openshift is an enterprise-ready open source container application platform built on top of Kubernetes. It facilitates deployment of applications on cloud infrastructure. It can be used as either a public cloud service from major cloud service providers such as AWS, Azure, Google or as a self-managed software on the broad spectrum of on-premise and virtual infrastructure across data centre, public clouds and edge.
Openshift® is built on top of Kubernetes and extends Kubernetes with additional features, such as integrated developer tools, enhanced security, and simplified deployment and management capabilities.

header: Requirements for deploying Blue Planet products using Kubernetes platform

content.text: This section covers guidelines and requirements to deploy Blue Planet products using the Kubernetes services supported by AWS, Azure, and Google. The section covers:
content.header: Requirements for deploying Blue Planet products using Kubernetes platform
Requirements for deploying Blue Planet products using Kubernetes platform

content.text: You can deploy Blue Planet products on Kubernetes platform in a multi-host configuration environment.

A multi-host configuration consists of multiple hosts at the same site, where all nodes in the cluster are active by default. Multi-host cluster deployment is more complex than the single pod deployment. However, it is more resilient to hardware failures and is suitable for horizontal scaling.

If products are deployed in multi-host mode, it is recommended that the cluster has at least three nodes. To users of a solution user interface (UI) and northbound API clients, this multi-host configuration looks like a single logical unit. It is accessed using a virtual Site IP address. This Site IP address redirects requests to the appropriate node in the cluster.

You can design your multi-host cluster in such a way that ensures availability and continuity of services to users, irrespective of a network disaster, which might occur due to reasons such as power outage, network breakdown, configuration issues, and so on.
To recover from a disaster in real-time, Blue Planet supports following recovery options:
A Kubernetes architecture consists of two primary components:

The Control plane contains master nodes that manage worker nodes in a Kubernetes cluster. It directly interacts with all external connections via API and communicates with worker nodes to manage them according to the real time requirements. The Control plane takes important decisions such as cluster configurations, scheduling, load balancing, and so on.

To achieve high availability, these worker nodes are dispersed across multiple availability zones. Kubernetes takes several factors into account before allocating a Pod to a worker node, such as resource availability, node availability, tolerations, affinity rules, and anti-affinity rules.
Kubernetes ensures HA at both the node level and Pod level.

The node-level resilience is assured by the multi-node architecture and scalability features of Kubernetes. In multi-node architecture, workloads run on multiple instances spread across multiple worker nodes, If a worker node goes down, Kubernetes automatically schedules Pods running on that worker node to other worker nodes that are up and running, thus maintaining the high availability of services for users in real time.

Even if an app is running as a single instance in one Pod, and the node that is running it crashes, Kubernetes creates a new Pod on another available and healthy node that meets its requirements. In that way, Kubernetes recovers from node crashes even for single-instance apps.

Geographic Redundancy is the replication of your data in two geographically separate and interconnected sites (Active and Standby) to ensure that your data remains intact and is always available if a disaster happens. In the case of a disaster, your applications immediately switch from the impacted site to the redundant or standby site.

The two sites communicate using secure IPsec tunnels. Clients connect to the Active site which actively manages the network and maintains sessions to the managed devices. All data hosted on the active site is continuously and automatically replicated to the Standby site. Therefore, if a disaster happens at the active site, the standby site takes over the control and becomes the primary active site and starts providing seamless uninterrupted services to the users.
For more information about the GR deployment, refer to the Kubernetes deployment guides for Blue Planet products.

header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: Regions are separate geographic areas that cloud servicer providers use to house its infrastructure. These regions are distributed around the world to enable customers to choose a region closest to them for hosting their cloud infrastructure. The closer is a region to you, the quicker is the service delivery for you, with reduced network latency.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: An Availability Zone (AZ) consists of multiple data centers connected to each other over redundant low latency private network links. Each region typically has multiple AZs. These AZs are inter-connected and communicate with each other continuously over redundant low-latency network links.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: So, if you design your infrastructure to have backups of data in other AZs, you build a very efficient model of resiliency and distributed computing, the core concepts of cloud computing.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: For example, if you distribute your instances across multiple Availability Zones and one instance fails, you can design your application such that an instance in another Availability Zone can handle service requests, ensuring high availability, resiliency, fault-tolerance, and scalability.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: Following GR deployment scenario is supported for deployment of Blue Planet products on Kubernetes:

In this multi-host configuration scenario, the deployment is done across multiple AZs and multiple Regions, and the deployment of different solution components is distributed across multiple AZs, So, the service delivery continues even of an Az within the primary region fails or the whole region fails.

This deployment scenario is the most resilient, stable, fault-tolerant, and secure. However, it may have performance issues due to the latency in communication between cluster hosts, which will impact processes like load-sharing, load-balancing.

You can deploy Blue Planet products on BP2 platform in a single-host or multi-host configuration.

A single-host configuration consists of one host at a site. This type of configuration does not support redundancy, fault tolerance capability, or scalability. If the host goes down, the entire service stops until the host becomes up and running. Hence the single host deployment is not a recommended for production purposes.

A multi-host configuration consists of multiple hosts at the same site, where all nodes in the cluster are active by default. Multi-host cluster deployment is more complex than the single pod deployment. However, it is more resilient to hardware failures and is suitable for horizontal scaling.

If products are deployed in multi-host mode, it is recommended that the cluster has at least three nodes. To users of a solution user interface (UI) and northbound API clients, this multi-host configuration looks like a single logical unit. It is accessed using a virtual Site IP address. This Site IP address redirects requests to the appropriate node in the cluster.

You can design your multi-host cluster in such a way that ensures availability and continuity of services to users, irrespective of a network disaster, which might occur due to reasons such as power outage, network breakdown, configuration issues, and so on.
To recover from a disaster in real-time, Blue Planet supports following recovery options:

HA provides capabilities that allow a site’s primary functionality to remain operational in response to a failure of a component on that site. Blue Planet achieves this continuity of service through redundant or fault-tolerant components on supported server clusters.
In the Blue Planet HA deployment, Blue Planet software runs across a cluster of hosts in a site, rather than on a single host.

If one of the hosts in the cluster goes down, requests are redirected to other working hosts. However, users are not aware of this hosts switching activity, and they continue performing their operations without any interruption.
In order for HA to function properly, it is required that:

Geographic Redundancy is the replication of your data in two geographically separate and interconnected sites (Active and Standby) to ensure that your data remains intact and is always available if a disaster happens. In the case of a disaster, your applications immediately switch from the impacted site to the redundant or standby site.

The two sites communicate using secure IPsec tunnels. Clients connect to the Active site which actively manages the network and maintains sessions to the managed devices. All data hosted on the active site is continuously and automatically replicated to the Standby site. Therefore, if a disaster happens at the active site, the standby site takes over the control and becomes the primary active site and starts providing seamless uninterrupted services to the users.

Blue Planet Inventory (BPI) does not support horizontal scaling by adding hosts in a multi-host configuration. Larger networks, user communities, and transactional loads are handled by vertically scaling the host(s) deployed.

header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: Regions are separate geographic areas that cloud servicer providers use to house its infrastructure. These regions are distributed around the world to enable customers to choose a region closest to them for hosting their cloud infrastructure. The closer is a region to you, the quicker is the service delivery for you, with reduced network latency.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: An Availability Zone (AZ) consists of multiple data centers connected to each other over redundant low latency private network links. Each region typically has multiple AZs. These AZs are inter-connected and communicate with each other continuously over redundant low-latency network links.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: So, if you design your infrastructure to have backups of data in other AZs, you build a very efficient model of resiliency and distributed computing, the core concepts of cloud computing.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: For example, if you distribute your instances across multiple Availability Zones and one instance fails, you can design your application such that an instance in another Availability Zone can handle service requests, ensuring high availability, resiliency, fault-tolerance, and scalability.
content.header: Regions and Availability Zones in cloud

content.text: Following GR deployment scenarios are supported for deployment of Blue Planet products:

In this multi-host configuration scenario, the deployment is performed in a single AZ within a Region, with active and standby are configured in the same region. This type of deployment does ensures local redundancy, but does not always ensure service continuity, because, if the whole Region goes down, the entire service stops until the Region is recovered from disaster successfully.

In this multi-host configuration scenario, the deployment is done in a single AZ across multiple Regions. This deployment scenario is more resilient and stable than the previous one. If one Region fails, the other configured Region starts providing services.

This deployment scenario is the most resilient, stable, fault-tolerant, and secure. However, it may have performance issues due to the latency in communication between cluster hosts, which will impact processes like load-sharing, load-balancing.

In a setup, assuming a network of size of 1.7M end points collecting 400M metrics/hour, constant stream of 800 alarms and 700 logs per second, having bandwidth of 400mbps, and 50ms latency(can support upto 100ms), following server sizing recommendations are given – It will require 5 hosts to support 400M metrics/hour.

This network is having a combination of a direct network managing around 500k End points, 100M Metrics/hour, two remote collector sites - one RC managing 1M End points, 250M Metrics/hour and another RC present in a remote area managing 200k end points, 50M Metrics/hour.
Below are the hardware specifications required for remote collectors :
Table 117. Hardware Specifications for Remote Collectors
To Support 1.2M End points and 300M Metrics per hour, 5 Node cluster is needed with overall bandwidth of 300mbps between the main site & the remote site.
The Maximum End point size that is supported in a 5 node cluster is 2M but the requirement as per the example is only 1.7M

NiFi uses site to site communication to transfer data between main site and remote site. S2S -1 & S2S -2 are the two site to site connections between the main site & the remote site. S2S -1 is communication between 3 node RC & the main cluster requires minimum of 200mbps bandwidth and S2S -2 is communication between a standalone RC and the main cluster requires a minimum bandwidth of 100mbps.
Bandwidth of 300mbps is required to support the requirement with latency supported upto 100ms.
This section covers server requirements for deployment of Blue Planet MLA (UAA-ROA) on small, medium, or large hosts on lab and production environments.

Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (EC2) enables you to select optimum instance types that follow the requirements of your applications resources. You are normally advised to use either Compute Optimized or Memory Optimized instances to deploy Blue Planet UAA-ROA. However, considering the specific usage requirements for UAA-ROA, you should use the Compute Optimized instance with the Elastic Block Storage (EBS)-Only storage to deploy UAA-ROA.

The following tables list the recommended AWS and Azure instance types and required resources based on the instance size. The instance size is determined by a number of factors related to the customer network size and complexity.
Factors such as the number of advertised IP prefixes, number of MPLS tunnels, number of VPN services, and collection of performance and/or IP Flow data (Netflow) determine the required instance size.
As per lab experiments, both (IGP) and (BGP) work well with network latency: 250 milliseconds round trip time (RTT) between UAA-ROA cloud instance and customer network routers.

The instance type c5n.9xlarge or c5n.18xlarge is required only for very high network throughput. A larger disk size will allow UAA-ROA to store more historical data for planning and post-mortem analysis. Please work with your Blue Planet Account team to determine the storage requirements for your system.

content.text: UAA supports up to 100ms latency between Active and Standby sites. Bandwidth requirements depend on the size of the network and metrics polled per hour. Refer to the following table.
Higher latency and the data (FM + PM) size will have impact on the time taken to setup a new standby site.

For example, with a network of size 2M Endpoints having incoming alarm rate of 200 Alarms/sec, Fault Event rate of 500 Events/sec and Performance collection at 400M metrics/hour, the total bandwidth required will be 305 MBps.

In a Simple setup, assuming a network of size 40K nodes collecting 350M metrics/hour with 14 day raw, 30days one hour and 365 days one day retention data, following server sizing recommendations are given – It will require a 4 hosts (3+1) cluster to support 350M metrics/hour.
